content: Hi @T-compiler/meeting ; we will be starting our planning meeting in about 3 minutes
(I apologize for failing to post a reminder about it during triage yesterday)
@oli what does :octopus: signify? Too many parallel tasks?
Or is it that octopi are well known for their planning?
I thought it was a squiggly "hurray"
though... I do have this meeting somewhat double booked
(yes, I know I'm on vacation lol)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QTEa-lClAQ0
(I wonder whom that "Do not feed" note is for.)
Okay, hi again @T-compiler/meeting

lets start off with five minutes for

Announcements
what's the topic today?
@nagisa planning
Its possible though that there are no new proposals of significance
This is what we have listed now: https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3Ameeting-proposal+-label%3Ameeting-scheduled
but, for example, we had the perf.rlo discussion already. I just failed to update its metadata accordingly
Would it be worth trying to do some planning for the upcoming compiler team sprint if there are no other meeting proposals to discuss?
There are two proposals that we could arguably schedule

• compiler-team#400: perf triage report construction
  • compiler-team#401: regression day
but I think the reality there is that regression day has been effective not as a design meeting
but rather a small zoom session (that should be publicized) with the compiler leads and someone from @T-infra @T-release (namely @simulacrum )
and I think its premature to have a design meeting about perf triage report construction. We have some volunteers who said they would work with @rylev and @pnkfelix on general perf triage issues
So, basically, I'm coming around to agreeing with you, @Wesley Wiser , that we could either spend this time right now on sprint planning
or we could schedule a future Friday meeting for sprint planning
(or both)
personally, I'm not prepared to say much about the sprint myself
other than: its going to be upon us sooner than I expected (or at least that's the way I feel)
I still think the plan to focus on memory usage makes sense.
I'm trying to recall if we have a list of ideas of how to improve memory usage. Or even just a list of things to investigate.
I haven't seen it :)
So there was one point I hadn't really thought about
mentioned over in #t-compiler/performance > lets keep talking about perf.rlo , namely this comment
which said that the memory usage peaks are due to LLVM
this has a couple different implications

Well, certainly not for check builds :)

But the point stands that it may be a problem.
1. trying to monitor/instrument memory usage by swapping in a different #[global_allocator] won't capture LLVM's memory usage
(unless LLVM has some hooks to swap in a different allocator that we could actually expose up to the Rust level. But I'm going to assume that's not the case for now.)
so, okay: That just means that we need to stick to traditional memory profiler tools

There are a couple of avenues we could explore in order to improve memory utilization in LLVM: better scheduling of codegen units (there have been some improvements recently) and better codegen unit collection.
Could I get a show of :+1: / :-1: on each comment below for people to say whether (:+1:) or not (:-1:) they've used a certain tool?
Like, this statement: "I consider myself an expert in using massif"
"I have used OS X's environment variables to observe behavior of its std memory allocator"
hmm
"I have at least one tool I can think of reaching for when I have a memory usage issue on a program"
Okay: Lets hear the tools
top
DHAT
DHAT is an…
Valgrind tool
yeah, I just wanted to say that DHAT is a tool I would generally reach for before massif, but you posted DHAT before I finished crafting my message ^^
It really is a shame that njn cannot dedicate as much time as they used to.
Archemedes' Method (ducks)
Lets do the statement thing again then
"I have used DHAT at least once"
"I consider myself an expert in using and interpreting DHAT results"
Moderately good perhaps :)
I think there's an opportunity here
Rustc's datastructure layout output is a valid memory reduction/profiling tool.
I recall using a memory profiler as part of OS X's Instruments several years ago and it seemed to work ok.
I've been assuming that one can run into scenarios where jemalloc and rustc are using different allocators
but I just realized that perhaps that sort of configuration is not in fact supported
(its something I've been meaning to look into)
As far as visualization goes, I had pretty nice experience with the chrome/firefox devtools, but a question would be how to get the data into there.
Does anyone know offhand if things obviously break if the two systems are using different allocators? (For example, do we ever free things from the rustc side that we allocated by LLVM?)
(My memory is that we've tried to avoid getting into such a situation.)
Much like elsewhere in FFI you typically have no other choice than to call the library's provided free function anyway.

The reason why I ask this is because I was wondering about @matklad 's reference to Archimedes' Method, and whether it potentially breaks down, or at least fails to cover some of the memory usage, due to that issue.
okay. Were there any other kinds of tooling people were thinking of?

so far it seems like there's a general circling around DHAT as being the most common tool people might reach for, but almost no one considers themselves an expert in it. if I'm interpreting this correctly.
So the opportunity I see is to actually try to come up with dedicated tutorial/training on using DHAT with rustc
some mix of screen casts and rust-dev guide chapter
and to produce this in advance of the sprint
so that we can all be on the same page about what tools we are using to evaluate memory usage
/me would like to see if he could do some profiling on Windows as well
I believe I can dedicate significant time to this myself, but I would like other people to also participate, either in producing content as well, or at least in reviewing the content I generate.
@rylev that's true. Does valgrind work if you have WSL ?
https://www.deleaker.com/blog/2020/01/04/valgrind-for-windows/
that is a blog post from some tool called "deleaker" that's promoting itself as the valgrind for windows.
I've used valgrind on WSL but not in an serious way
(deleaker is not really valgrind for windows. Its using a different implementation strategy)
I'd like to try with the MSVC toolchain since that's a bit more "native" to Windows (and perhaps more likely to yield results different enough from other platforms to be of interest)
That makes sense
I would probably reach for visual studio on Windows first, too
also deleaker is commericial software
so yeah, not ideal
okay
in terms of what I should focus on myself
or
hmm
okay, one more quick poll
I'm going to ask about what dev OS people focus on using: Mac/Linux/Windows. For Mac, :apple: , for Linux, :penguin: , for Windows, :door:
(oh, and "other" is :upside_down: ) so, yeah, choose one or more, but stick to things you think of as "primary" dev environments)
Okay, so far my interpretation is that there's little reason, based on the people present here, for us to produce training specifically addressing features/issues on Mac.
(Oh no! :sweat_smile:)
I'm hoping that the Linux training will mostly be applicable to Mac, perhaps with sidenotes/caveats
I'm just saying there's little benefit in talking about how to use Instruments.app
(not an expert in this area, worry about mac specific problems that might crop up, but prior comment in jest)
I'd be interested in helping produce dev-guide content on Windows memory profiling
yes, the mac specific problems worry me too. We've seen them elsewhere, and need to be aware of them.
@Esteban Küber do you think you'd have time to partner up with me on reviewing content?
Yes
great
@rylev I'd be happy to do the same for you, review your content that is
I'm happy to try the instructions on :penguin:, :door: and some of the :upside_down:
okay. the only other thing I'd like to figure out is when we need to publish by for this to be useful
we could obviously do a "publish early and iterate" approach
for at least some of it
and we may want guidance on how long to make a screencasts
what kind of attention span do you kids have these days? :laughing:
I already said I'd want it published before the sprint, which will be first week of March
and maybe that's good enough, i.e. having it published in two weeks would probably be fine
but I suspect having an early edition up sooner would be great
We can publish drafts, right?
definitely
But even if we did that, how will people find out about the material?
should we make a dedicated zulip thread, and maybe an internals.rlo as well?
(and an inside rust blog post when we put up the "nearly finalized" versions, maybe?)
I think ideally we would go into the sprint with a handful of ideas of what to fix, which implies that we've already done profiling and found hot spots before the sprint week starts.
anyway I think this is a really good outcome of this meeting
that's a good point
so maybe part of the work in making these docs is to also gather that data
and post hypotheses of things to work on
my goal was to make sure that everyone had the resources they would need to help contribute
but it won't help to have those resources if there are no proposed action items at the start of the sprint
Should I perhaps make a #t-compiler/shrinkmem-sprint-planning stream where people can post notes/ideas as they explore the tools?
(I'm not going to do it without some encouragement... but I'm also open to other ideas for how to collect ideas into one place. github issues in a dedicated shrinky-sprint github repo?)
An issue or a hackmd would also work, methinks
yeah I guess its a question of whether we want to encourage dialogue on github, which I tend to find painful.
We need a scratchpad easy to edit, a thread might not be ideal
zulip topics where each starts with a link to a dedicated hackmd could be a good pattern
(we need threading, /me misses google wave)
(same would work for github issues on a dedicated repo, I suppose.)
Maybe today's world is ready for Google Wave
anyway

I don't want today's meeting to end without resolving where the hypotheses and proposed action items for the sprint are going to be collected. @Wesley Wiser , do you have opinions on the ideas posted, or new ideas of your own?
I think I'm leaning towards a repo, to be honest
we might need to be adding attachments with datasets
that kind of thing
and zulip as the central space for that sounds non-ideal.
I think I would lean toward a HackMD file multiple people can collaborate on but a repo is fine too :)
okay. Maybe lets start with a hackmd
if it grows unmanageable, then we migrate it
to something with more structure, and install a forwarding pointer
Part of the workflow could be HackMD for ideas & trying stuff out and then put actual findings in a repo and create issues for potential sprint week work items.
to be clear: do we have a hackmd plus a dedicated zulip stream? or just a zulip topic in #t-compiler ?
i think I want a zulip stream for the sprint
so i might as well make that now
I think that's a good idea.
Okay I just created #t-compiler/shrinkmem-sprint
and look at that, I did something just in time for the meeting to end.
So just to review
action items are:
1. @pnkfelix to work on DHAT training material for Linux. Partnered with @Esteban Küber for review
1. @rylev to work on analogous training material oriented at Windows users. Partnered with @pnkfelix for review
1. We all go add ourselves to #t-compiler/shrinkmem-sprint , and try to establish pattern of posting ideas in a shared hackmd (to be created)
(presumably after its created someone will say something in a topic in #t-compiler/shrinkmem-sprint )
okay, that was great
thanks to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending!!! have a happy valentines day, for those of you who are into that kind of thing. :heart: :hearts: :heart_eyes:

pnkfelix said:

(presumably after its created someone will say something in a topic in #t-compiler/shrinkmem-sprint )

done: #t-compiler/shrinkmem-sprint > brainstorming hackmd

pnkfelix said:

to something with more structure, and install a forwarding pointer

/me's GC background leaks through
